text.tspan: 8.34KOhm
This is used to create a mask for the DLP LCD of a UV resin printer. This describes the calculation method
used to determine the local mask intensity. The big black line represents the resistance measurement
results using a LDR where the numbers represent the duty cycle of the DLP LCD (8-bit from 1 to 256).
Across this line multiple measurements have been made to determine the characteristics of the LDR. This is
performed on the brightest spot on the LCD. A 6th order polynomial curve of this data is created, so we can
put in a resistance value and have the mask intensity value (from 1 to 256) returned. The smaller green line
represents 2 measurements of any less brighter spot, for which we want to know the local mask intensity
required to have a brightness equal to the (arbritrarily chosen) value of 8.34KOhm. This is the value that the entire
LCD screen brightness must be adjusted to, making use of the mask. So to reduce the brightness of the les
bright spot we need to know which mask intensity value for that particular location we can use.
4.26KOhm
22.79KOhm
1) The lowest mask intensity value of 192 of a secundairy spot is converted to a mask intensity
value using the polynomial curve fit of the brightest spot on the screen. Resulting in 161.
2) The same is done for the highest mask intensity value of the secundairy spot, resulting in 229.
3) The difference of these values is determined, which is 229 - 161 = 68.
4) The difference between the min and max mask intensity of the secundairy spot is calculated,
resulting in 64.
5) These values are brought into ratio by 64 / 68 = 0.941
6) The resistance value of 8.34KOhm, we want the secundairy spot to be adjusted to by the
yet to determine mask intensity (?) is put in the curve fit to determine the mask intensity of the
brightest spot that would equal this light intensity, which is 211.
7) Then the difference of this value, and the min mask intensity is determined: 211 - 161 = 50.
8) The ratio determined at point 5, and the value of 50 determined at point 7 are multiplied.
So the mask intensity difference of the brightest spot of value 50, would be equal to
50 x 0.941 = 47.05 difference in mask intensity of the secundairy spot.
9) Then finally, the minimum value of the secundairy spot is added to obtain 192 + 47.05 = 239
as the mask intensity to apply to the secundairy spot to have a light brightness equal to the LDR
measured resistance of 8.34KOhm.
